samples.prompt: EpicFlow: Edge-Preserving Interpolation of Correspondences for Optical Flow Jerome Revauda Philippe Weinzaepfela Zaid Harchaouia,b Cordelia Schmida a Inria b NYU firstname.lastname@inria.fr Abstract We propose a novel approach for optical ow estima- tion, targeted at large displacements with signi cant oc- clusions. It consists of two steps: i) dense matching by
samples.target: edge-preserving interpolation from a sparse set of matches; ii) variational energy minimization initialized with the dense matches. The sparse-to-dense interpolation relies on an appropriate choice of the distance, namely an edge- aware geodesic distance. This distance is tailored to han- dle occlusions and motion boundaries two common and dif cult issues for optical ow computation. We also pro- pose an approximation scheme for the geodesic distance to allow fast computation without loss of performance. Sub- sequent to the dense interpolation step, standard one-level variational energy minimization is carried out on the dense matches to obtain the nal ow estimation. The
samples.base_model_continuation: by a multi-scale correspondence search, and ii) edge-preserving interpolation of the ow direction. Our method, called EpicFlow, is robust to occlusions and enables accurate ow estimation on large-scale datasets. We evaluate it on the KITTI dataset and show that it outperforms the state-of-the-art. samples.prompt: Burst Deblurring: Removing Camera Shake Through Fourier Burst Accumulation Mauricio Delbracio Guilermo Sapiro ECE, Duke University {mauricio.delbracio, guillermo.sapiro}duke.edu Abstract Numerous recent approaches attempt to remove im- age blur due to camera shake, either with one or mul- tiple input images, by explicitly solving an inverse and inherently ill-posed deconvolution problem.
samples.target: If the pho- tographer takes a burst of images, a modality available in virtually all modern digital cameras, we show that it is possible to combine them to get a clean sharp version. This is done without explicitly solving any blur estimation and subsequent inverse problem. The proposed algorithm is strikingly simple: it performs a weighted average in the Fourier domain, with weights depending on the Fourier spectrum magnitude. The method s rationale is that camera shake has a random nature and therefore each image in the burst is gener- ally blurred di erently. Experiments with real camera data show
samples.base_model_continuation:
. In this work, we present a novel approach to remove camera shake from images using a single input image. Our algorithm is based on Fourier burst accumulation and is robust to the presence of motion blur. Our results are competitive with the state-of-the-art approaches in terms of performance and computational complexity.

samples.finetuned_model_continuation: . In this paper, we propose an alternative method to remove camera shake. Our approach relies on a single input image and, in contrast to the aforementioned approaches, does not require the use of any additional images or blur kernels. We propose a novel technique, the multi-task joint learning, which jointly trains a localization model and a classifier to distinguish between the target objects and the non-target objects. To deal with the ambiguities in the training data, we propose a data-driven method to extract the most discriminative attributes from the training data.

Rec., Shenzhen Institutes of Advanced Technology, CAS, China 2 Department of Electronic Engineering, The Chinese University of Hong Kong wlouyang@ee.cuhk.edu.hk, xgwang@ee.cuhk.edu.hk Abstract In this paper, we address the challenging
samples.target: problem of de- tecting pedestrians who appear in groups and have inter- action. A new approach is proposed for single-pedestrian detection aided by multi-pedestrian detection. A mixture model of multi-pedestrian detectors is designed to capture the unique visual cues which are formed by nearby multi- ple pedestrians but cannot be captured by single-pedestrian detectors. A probabilistic framework is proposed to model the relationship between the con gurations estimated by single- and multi-pedestrian detectors, and to re ne the single-pedestrian detection result with multi-pedestrian de- tection. We present a novel two-stage framework, which consists of a single-pedestrian detector and a multi-pedestrian detector. The single-pedestrian detector is a convolutional neural network based on the Faster R-CNN. samples.prompt: Graph-based Simplex Method for Pairwise Energy Minimization with Binary Variables Daniel Pr u sa Center for Machine Perception, Faculty of Electrical Engineering, Czech Technical University Karlovo n am est 13, 121 35 Prague, Czech Republic prusapa1@fel.cvut.cz Abstract We show how the simplex algorithm can be tailored to the linear programming
samples.target: relaxation of pairwise energy min- imization with binary variables. A special structure formed by basic and nonbasic variables in each stage of the algo- rithm is identi ed and utilized to perform the whole iterative process combinatorially over the input energy minimization graph rather than algebraically over the simplex tableau. This leads to a new ef cient solver. We demonstrate that for some computer vision instances it performs even better than methods reducing binary energy minimization to nd- ing maximum ow in a network. 1. samples.base_model_continuation: programming problem of minimizing the pairwise energy of a set of binary variables. We present a fast algorithm that runs in O(n3) time and that can find the optimal solution. We show that our method can be applied to a wide range of problems that can be formulated as pairwise energy minimization problems. The proposed method can be used in many applications where pairwise energy minimization is used as a method to minimize the number of interactions. The main idea is to use a variant of the simplex algorithm that can be applied
samples.finetuned_model_continuation: programming formulation of the energy minimization problem of graph-based image segmentation. This allows us to use the well known simplex algorithm for the solution of the energy minimization problem. The new approach can be used for fast and ef cient pairwise energy minimization in graph-based image segmentation. It is particularly useful for the segmentation of highly complex images. Our method is evaluated on the popular benchmark dataset of 200 images, where it outperforms the state-of-the-art methods by a large margin.

samples.prompt: Deep Sparse Representation for Robust Image Registration Yeqing Li 1, Chen Chen 1, Fei Yang2, and Junzhou Huang1 1University of Texas at Arlington 2Facebook Inc. Abstract The de nition of the similarity measure is an essential component in image registration. In this paper, we propose a novel similarity measure for
samples.target: registration of two or more images. The proposed method is motivated by that the opti- mally registered images can be deeply sparsi ed in the gra- dient domain and frequency domain, with the separation of a sparse tensor of errors. One of the key advantages of the proposed similarity measure is its robustness to severe in- tensity distortions, which widely exist on medical images, remotely sensed images and natural photos due to the dif- ference of acquisition modalities or illumination conditions. Two ef cient algorithms are proposed to solve the batch im- age registration and pair registration problems in a
samples.base_model_continuation: for image registration based on deep sparse representation. The proposed similarity measure is designed to capture the sparse-ness of the image features, which is a key property in image registration. To capture the sparse-ness of the image features, we develop a deep sparse representation framework, which consists of a deep convolutional neural network and a sparse coding layer. The proposed framework is capable of capturing the sparse-ness of the image features and can be used to measure the similarity of two images. The proposed similarity measure can be

Our method is shown to be more robust than the state-of-the-art methods in terms of the effect of image noise and outliers. 1. samples.prompt: Fast Energy Minimization using Learned State Filters Matthieu Guillaumin ETH Z urich guillaumin@vision.ee.ethz.ch Luc Van Gool ETH Z urich, KU Leuven vangool@vision.ee.ethz.ch Vittorio Ferrari University of Edinburgh ferrari@inf.ed.ac.uk Abstract Pairwise discrete energies de ned over graphs are ubiq- uitous in computer vision. Many algorithms have been pro- posed to minimize
samples.target: such energies, often concentrating on sparse graph topologies or specialized classes of pairwise potentials. However, when the graph is fully connected and the pairwise potentials are arbitrary, the complexity of even approximate minimization algorithms such as TRW-S grows quadratically both in the number of nodes and in the number of states a node can take. Moreover, recent appli- cations are using more and more computationally expen- sive pairwise potentials. These factors make it very hard to employ fully connected models. In this paper we pro- pose a novel, generic algorithm to approximately minimize any discrete pairwise energy function. Our method
samples.base_model_continuation: minimize these energies using the conjugate gradient method. This paper presents a new method that does not require a costly gradient computation. The algorithm consists of ﬁnding a set of learned state filters that minimize the energy. The state filters are learned from data and can be updated at run-time. The algorithm is used to ﬁnd the minimum of the pairwise discrete energy over a graph of a set of 3D objects. The results are compared to the conjugate gradient method. The learned state filters also allow for
samples.finetuned_model_continuation: minimize them. However, they are usually slow and do not converge for some classes of graphs. We propose a new minimization method based on the idea of discrete optimization. It is based on an iterative procedure which is similar to the discrete gradient descent method for continuous optimization. The new method is very fast (less than 100 iterations for most graphs) and converges for all graphs, as long as the discrete energy is convex.
